title: My Weird Winter Experiment with Bourbon Vanilla Tallow Balm
body:
Look, I need to talk about this beef tallow balm I’ve been putting on my face. The bourbon vanilla one. It sounds insane. I know. My friend sent me a link to this Etsy shop back in December, when the air got that dry, crackly feel, and I was just desperate. My forehead looked like a dried-up riverbed. I’d tried the expensive stuff in the fancy jars, the ones that cost more than my electric bill, and nothing. So I clicked. Beef fat skincare. Sure. Why not. Let’s put cooking grease on my face, that’ll help. That was my whole thought process.

Anyway, it showed up. The jar was smaller than I thought. Cute, though. I opened it in my kitchen, under that weird yellow overhead light. Smelled like vanilla maybe? Or not. Something. Like vanilla extract spilled on a warm leather chair. I poked it. Texture was weird. Not bad weird. Like cold butter whipped with air. I put a tiny bit on the back of my hand just to see. Cold at first. Then not. I don’t know how to describe it. It just sort of vanished into my skin. No greasy film. My hand felt… quiet. That’s the only word. The skin just stopped feeling tight and angry. I stood there for a minute, staring at my hand. Huh.

## How I Even Got Here (Blame My Grandma)

So the whole tallow thing. I fell down an internet hole one night. Couldn’t sleep. Started reading about traditional skincare. Not the 10-step routines, but the old stuff. Like, centuries old. Turns out, using animal fats on skin isn’t some new crunchy trend. It’s ancient. My own grandma, when I was a kid, she had this little tin of something for her knuckles in winter. I asked her once what it was. She just said “ointment” and waved her hand. I’m betting it was lard or something similar. People used what they had. Beef tallow—that’s the rendered fat from around a cow’s kidneys—was a big one. It’s stable. Doesn’t go rancid fast. And get this: its fatty acid profile is supposedly really close to our own skin’s sebum. So your skin recognizes it. It’s like giving your skin something it already knows how to use, instead of some lab-made silicone cocktail.

It makes a stupid amount of sense when you think about it. For generations, it was just… what you did. Then the 20th century happened. Everything got processed, packaged, marketed. “Clean” beauty meant squeaky-clean chemicals with unpronounceable names. The idea of putting a pure, single-ingredient animal fat on your face became “gross” or “backwards.” But now? People are circling back. They’re tired of 30-ingredient lists where half the stuff is filler or fragrance. They want simple. Effective. The traditional tallow skincare comeback is literally just people remembering that sometimes, the old ways worked for a reason.

## What This Bourbon Vanilla Stuff Actually Does

Okay. So the product. This Whipped Tallow Balm. It’s from some small maker in France, I think. Grass-fed cows. They take the suet, render it clean, whip it up with some bourbon vanilla oil. That’s basically it. The whipping makes it fluffy, so it’s not like scooping hard wax. You take a little dab, warm it between your fingers, and press it in. Don’t rub it around like lotion. Just press.

Here’s the weird part. I started using it at night. After I wash my face. I’d do my whole skeptical side-eye at the jar, grab a bit, and pat it on. The first few nights, I didn’t notice much. My skin felt softer in the morning, but I figured it was a fluke. Then, maybe a week in, I was putting on makeup and I stopped. My foundation. It just… sat differently. No clinging to dry patches around my nose. No cakey mess on my forehead. It looked like I had moisturizer on under it, but I didn’t. I just had the tallow balm from the night before. My skin was just… hydrated. Not dewy in a shiny way. Just even. Calm.

I got braver. Used it on my hands. My cuticles were a mess from winter and constant hand-washing. After a couple days, the cracking stopped. I started slathering it on my elbows before bed. They haven’t been this smooth since I was a kid, I don’t know when. It’s not a miracle. It doesn’t make you look 20 again. But for dry skin relief? For that tight, itchy, winter-skin feeling? It just… takes it away. The scent is this warm, comforting thing. Not sugary vanilla. Deeper. Cozy. Like a bakery at the end of the day. It doesn’t smell like beef. At all. Which, thank god.

## My Skin After a Few Weeks of Beef Tallow

I’m probably a month in now. I use it almost every night. Sometimes in the morning if I’m feeling extra dry. My skin just feels more resilient. We had a brutal cold snap last week, the kind where the wind feels like needles. I walked the dog, came back inside, and my face didn’t have that raw, burning feeling. It just felt normal. That’s the win for me. Normal. Not perfect. Not “glowing.” Just comfortable in its own skin. I had a tiny patch of eczema on my wrist that’s been hanging around for ages. I started putting the tallow on it. It’s gone now. I’m not saying it’s a cure, but for me? It worked.

I told my sister about it. She laughed at me. Then she came over, tried it, and ordered a jar for herself the next day. She texted me last week: “my fine lines aren’t gone but my foundation isn’t gathering in them anymore what is this witchcraft.” That’s the thing. It doesn’t perform miracles. It performs… maintenance. Really, really good maintenance. It mimics what your skin is already trying to do. I’ve spent so much money on creams that promise to “repair the moisture barrier.” This feels like it just hands your skin the exact bricks it needs to do the repair itself.

Would I buy it again? I already did. I’m on my second jar. The first one lasted forever because you need so little. I got mine from this little Etsy shop, the one my friend sent me. It feels good to buy from a person, not a corporation. They just make the stuff and send it to you. No flashy ads. No influencers. Just… balm.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, I think so. For my skin, definitely. The science-y reason is that it’s similar to our skin’s own oils, so it absorbs well and doesn’t just sit on top clogging things. It’s like giving your skin food it actually knows how to digest.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Hasn’t for me. And I’m prone to getting clogged pores. I think because it absorbs so deeply, it doesn’t just block everything up. It’s the opposite of that heavy, pore-clogging feeling some thick creams have.

**What does bourbon vanilla tallow balm smell like?**
It’s warm. Like vanilla, but not from a candle. More like the smell of a vanilla bean pod, with a little depth to it. Not sweet. Just cozy. It doesn’t smell like kitchen grease at all, which was my biggest fear.

So yeah. That’s my tallow balm story. I went from “this is the weirdest thing I’ve ever bought” to having it as a permanent thing on my bedside table. If your skin is being difficult with the dry air, or you’re just tired of complicated products that don’t deliver, it might be worth a shot. It’s just one of those simple, traditional things that actually works. I don’t know what else to say. My skin’s happy. I’m happy. That’s all I wanted.
random_tangent: I told my sister about this
